titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Beqaa Arabic
titleStmt.author: Gunda Kinzl

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Mostly rural sedentary dialects, but also bedouin-type dialects.

The Beqaa valley is a fertile rural region in Eastern Lebanon, between the Mount Lebanon and the Anti-Lebanon-Mountains, close to the Syrian border. While the south and centre are apt for agriculture, the north is quite dry and used for pastoralism. It is famous for its agricultural production, but also infamous for the cultivation of cannabis and opium poppy.

The sectarian composition is diverse. The north is mostly Shia Muslim, with the exception of Deir el-Ahmar, which is Christian. Anjar has an Armenian Christian majority, while Joub Janine is predominantly Sunni Muslim. Zahlé, the district capital, is mostly Melkite Christian (Greek Catholic). There are significant numbers of Druze and various Christian denominations (such as Maronite Christians) and Sunni and Shia Muslims. Sectarian differences do make a linguistic difference, but no common sectarian dialect has developed

Grotzfeld 1973 offers a description of the dialect in Qsarnaba. Grotzfeld 1978 is a study in dialect geography on the Beqaa area and the neighbouring Rīf Dimašq area in Syria, drawing from fieldwork and building on earlier works by Bergsträßer 1915 and Fleisch 1974. Data in Behnstedt 1997 is collected from the above mentioned.

Younes 2014 is a description of the Šāwī Bedouin dialect of the Abu ˁĪd clan in the Beqaa valley. Younes and Bensaria 2017 describe contact phenomena between bedouin-type and sedentary dialects in the northern and central Beqaa.
Wardini’s article in the EALL offers examples from Zahlé and the Northern Beqaa valley town of Tal Sougha.
